Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: However if you just want data to say a blockchain can run at full block capacity, you could just point to BTC at the end of last year...  every block was full for months straight.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I dont see a need to prove what has already been proven.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: OK fair point.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: What has been the largest scale test tx/s to date?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The 1024 chain test.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: but they were 100 pyamnt TX's so the 20,000 number is far lower than theortically possible.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The 256 chain test, to test kubernetes should eclipse that number easily... theoretical maximum is ~37k tx/s.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: If we need higher than that we can use 512 chains to double it.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Either size will give us the data we need.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
It's pretty much processing bytes of tx data across a decentralized chain cluster.  Correct?

100 chains ~= 200MB/min
1000 chains = ~=2000MB/min
10000 chains = ~=20000MB/min

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: I want to build a template/HOWTO so others can take our work and implement their own test.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Possible now?  Or some doc gaps to fill ?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
for a single payment TX.... which is 1 vin to 2 vouts (your payment and the change returned to the first address) you can fit 8859 TX's into a 2MB block.
For a 100 payment TX, (1 vin to 101 vouts) you can fit 557 TX into a block. Anything inbwteeen should follow a fixed ratio, you can check this by creating some TX's and seeing how big the raw hex generated is. 
Each chain can process on average 2MB per minute,

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The transaction size also would work the other way, ie, combining 100 vins to 1 vout, to "join" the UTXO's back together.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: With this data you can do math to work out how many chains is required to achieve any required amount and size of transactions.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: My repo's would need some updating and some more docs for others to start at square 1, with no chains, and generate the JSON with the chain cluster parameters. But its not really that hard, with some updates to my scipts and docs, you can generate any number of chains in a cluster and all required scripts automatically to launch a notary node network to notarize them to KMD.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: It took me about 2H from zero notary network to a network of 4, and min sigs for a notarization of 2.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: In real world, I think min sigs would need to be more than 2 and notary nodes would need to be more than 4, however the compute resource required for these is pretty small. Biggest requirement is RAM and network bandwidth.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
This is great, thanks heaps üôè 
So, with your engineers hat on - in case it wasn't üòõ , a "real world" use case would have multiple vin:vout combos and there'd be many more addresses.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Yes.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Which is why I think we should describe it as maximum payments, however even then, the size of the transactions  will still vary and the amount of payments in a block will also vary. It totally depends on use case. Designing your cluster to run at capacity is also not clever, likey you would use 50-100% more chains than you 'need'.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
Pretty much bytes processing throughput, with a handful of variables that us clever humans use to measure these concepts as payments and transactions.
Noted re: deployment rationale.

Author: Hermes#6934
Content: Hi guys

Author: Hermes#6934
Content:
Question from a Telegram User:

45,000 TPS means you can handle 45,000 transactions per second.
transaction means one smartcontract.

However, Komodo's block generation cycle is one minute.
Does that mean that 45,000 X 60 = 2,700,000 tx/min is possible every minute?
Or is it possible to contract every second?

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: 45k tx/s but if you waiting for a confirmation, then yes 2,700,000 tx/min (with testing due soon to 60,000,000 tx/min 1st confirmation) & per contract if required when it get released, because contracts run in their own blockchain and implement cross-blockchain interoperability as per the crypto-conditions standard published by the IETF (internet engineering task force), that manage internet standards like IP addresses, DNS, email protocols etc.

Content: @Acura  this is the response
